children.name: Climate Change Adaptation
children.para: Build institutional capacity to manage and adapt to Climate Change. Guatemala is a country highly vulnerable to the impacts of Climate Change, which exacerbate extreme poverty and negatively affects growth opportunities. Climate variability and projected Climate Change will cause a decline in human development levels impacting food security, malnutrition, human health, natural ecosystems, and water resources. Building institutional capacities to address the impacts of Climate Change will be critical for Guatemalas development. Guatemala presented its Intended National Determined Contributions (INDC) in Paris, including existing and proposed country mitigation and Adaptation policies and plans, commitments and targets, and implementation strategies and sector priorities. Taking into consideration the countrys sectoral and geographic vulnerability, strategic sectors for Adaptation and Climate resilience have been prioritized, namely disaster risk management, agriculture and food security, degradation of natural resources (particularly forests), land use Changes, water and energy for the vulnerable, and marine and coastal systems. These priorities aim to improve development planning and scale the ability of Guatemala to adapt to the adverse impacts of Climate Change, while fostering Climate resilience and low greenhouse gas emissions development, in a sustainable manner. In this context, the WBG will support the Governments efforts to strengthen institutions and build capacity to increase resilience to Climate Change. . 5.1 Increased Government capacity to promote low carbon development, as measured by reduction of forest greenhouse gas emissions: Baseline: 0 (2016) Target: 3 million tons of CO2 (2020) 5.2 Percent of subprojects targeting Adaptation and mitigation needs of Indigenous peoples and vulnerable communities and fully achieving their objectives: Baseline: 0 percent (2016) Target: 50 percent (2020)

children.name: Financial Vulnerability and Risks
children.para: Enhance the enabling environment and increase access to finance for MSMEs. Lack of financing and weaknesses in the Financial environment constrain MSME growth. MSMEs are the backbone of the Guatemalan economy, contributing to 40 percent of GDP and 77 percent of the workforce. However, access to finance remains an important challenge, undermining the competitiveness and productivity of MSMEs. The lack of financing instruments, particularly loans, suitable for MSMEs hinder firm investment and growth, mainly because MSME financing is perceived by Financial institutions as a high risk lending activity, to a large extent due to the degree of informality and Vulnerability to domestic and external shocks associated with MSMEs. The WBG seeks to catalyze productive opportunities for greater employment, through increased access to finance for the countrys MSMEs. The expected outcome of this objective is to enhance the enabling environment and increase access to finance, so as to expand income and employment opportunities in the long-term. 3.1 Number of microfinance and SME finance loans provided through Financial services: Baseline: 93,133 (2015) Target: 141,723 (2020)

children.name: Health
children.para: Increase access to basic Health, nutrition & water & sanitation services . Addressing in the barriers to basic service provision is critical to resolving one of Guatemalas most significant developmental challenges, the persistently high rates of chronic malnutrition. The major drivers of chronic malnutrition are interlinked and include poor family planning, child feeding and early stimulation practices, food insecurity, limited access to safe water and sanitation, and insufficient and low quality Health services in rural and Indigenous areas. The Government is committed to working towards greater social inclusion by promoting equal access to basic services for all Guatemalans, and increasing availability of specialized services for women like peri-natal care and post rape care. Thus the expected outcome of this objective is better access to Health, nutrition, and water and sanitation services with focus on Indigenous peoples and other rural vulnerable groups, especially women and children. . 1.1 Percent of children 12 months old in the areas prioritized by the National Strategy to Reduce Chronic Malnutrition receiving the complete vaccination scheme required for their age:23 Baseline: 74 percent (2016) Target: 85 percent (2020) 1.2 Coverage of growth monitoring and promotion for children under 24 months in priority areas:24 Baseline: 10 percent (2016) Target: 50 percent (2020)

children.name: Governance Structures
children.para: Improve public resource management and accountability . Poor Governance in public resource management and lack of accountability hinders Guatemalas efforts to increase revenue collection. The low level of trust of Guatemalans in the States ability to transparently manage public resources has resulted in high tax non-compliance and overall culture of tax evasion. In 2014, SAT collected only 58 percent of potential VAT revenue. Non-compliance was further exacerbated by the political and institutional crisis in 2015 which revealed profound institutional weakness in SAT. The SAT suffers from a dysfunctional Governance structure, lack of adequate controls, excessive scope for discretionality, lack transparency in collection, and weak compliance mechanisms. Moreover, the transparency of the budgeting process is compromised by frequent use of alternate vehicles to implement programs, such as contracting under exception. Guatemalas human resources management system is fragmented, and lacks transparency, contributing to uncertainty regarding the size of the public sector workforce and the unpredictability of the wage bill. Lastly, weak antimoney laundering policies facilitate the injection of corruption proceeds into the financial system, reducing the risk of detection and confiscation of such funds. The expected outcome of this objective is that the Government improves public resource management and accountability. . 2.1 Estimated VAT non-compliance level (as a share of potential VAT revenues): Baseline: 34.2 percent (2015) Target: 29 percent (2020) 2.2 Compliance with customs inspections: Baseline: 6.3 percent (2016) Target: 12 percent (2020) 2.3 Share of public procurement executed through competitive processes as a percentage of the total value of executed public procurement: Baseline: 36 percent (2015) Target: 52 percent (2020

children.name: Ports
children.para:
Expand  infrastructure
. An underdeveloped infrastructure is one of the main obstacles to investment and economic development in Guatemala. Guatemalas infrastructure is dilapidated. In particular, the quality of the countrys port infrastructure has been deteriorating. Inefficient container handling capacity, antiquated infrastructure, high port congestion and inability to handle post-panamax vessels seriously undermine Guatemalas economic potential, and efforts to increase its productivity and competitiveness. This underdevelopment can be mostly attributed to low public infrastructure spending, and the lack of a fully functioning framework for PPPs to attract and mobilize private sector financing. Moreover, rapid and unplanned urbanization puts further pressure on Guatemalas already strained public resources and services. Over half of the countrys population of 15 million already live in urban and more than 40 percent of Guatemalas urbanites live in slums, one of the highest percentages in the region. The CPF seeks to contribute to the Governments efforts of expanding infrastructure and designing sustainable urban planning policies to foster sustainable growth. The expected outcome of this objective is that the Government expands infrastructure. 4.1 Increased port handling capacity:25 Baseline:  391,491 Twenty-Foot Equivalent    Unit (TEU) (2015) Target:           TBD      (2020) 4.2 Additional people26 in targeted urban areas provided with access to:  a) improved water sources: Baseline:      0  (2016) Target:  6,800  (2020) b) improved sanitation: Baseline:      0  (2016) Target:  9,700  (2020)

children.name: Ecosystems
children.para:
Increase access to basic health, nutrition & water & sanitation services
. Addressing in the barriers to basic service provision is critical to resolving one of Guatemalas most significant developmental challenges, the persistently high rates of chronic malnutrition. The major drivers of chronic malnutrition are interlinked and include poor family planning, child feeding and early stimulation practices, food insecurity, limited access to safe water and sanitation, and insufficient and low quality health services in rural and Indigenous areas. The Government is committed to working towards greater social inclusion by promoting equal access to basic services for all Guatemalans, and increasing availability of specialized services for women like peri-natal care and post rape care. Thus the expected outcome of this objective is better access to health, nutrition, and water and sanitation services with focus on Indigenous peoples and other rural vulnerable groups, especially women and children. . 1.1 Percent of children 12 months old in the areas prioritized by the National Strategy to Reduce Chronic Malnutrition receiving the complete vaccination scheme required for their age:23 Baseline: 74 percent (2016) Target:    85 percent (2020) 
 
1.2 Coverage of growth monitoring and promotion for children under 24 months in priority areas:24 Baseline: 10 percent (2016) Target:    50 percent (2020)

children.name: Infrastructure and Growth
children.para: Expand Infrastructure . An underdeveloped Infrastructure is one of the main obstacles to investment and economic development in Guatemala. Guatemalas Infrastructure is dilapidated. In particular, the quality of the countrys port Infrastructure has been deteriorating. Inefficient container handling capacity, antiquated Infrastructure, high port congestion and inability to handle post-panamax vessels seriously undermine Guatemalas economic potential, and efforts to increase its productivity and competitiveness. This underdevelopment can be mostly attributed to low public Infrastructure spending, and the lack of a fully functioning framework for PPPs to attract and mobilize private sector financing. Moreover, rapid and unplanned urbanization puts further pressure on Guatemalas already strained public resources and services. Over half of the countrys population of 15 million already live in urban and more than 40 percent of Guatemalas urbanites live in slums, one of the highest percentages in the region. The CPF seeks to contribute to the Governments efforts of expanding Infrastructure and designing sustainable urban planning policies to foster sustainable Growth. The expected outcome of this objective is that the Government expands Infrastructure. 4.1 Increased port handling capacity:25 Baseline: 391,491 Twenty-Foot Equivalent Unit (TEU) (2015) Target: TBD (2020) 4.2 Additional people26 in targeted urban areas provided with access to: a) improved water sources: Baseline: 0 (2016) Target: 6,800 (2020) b) improved sanitation: Baseline: 0 (2016) Target: 9,700 (2020)

children.name: Markets and Institutions for Poverty Reduction and Shared Prosperity
Finance and Growth
children.para: Enhance the enabling environment and increase access to Finance for MSMEs. Lack of financing and weaknesses in the financial environment constrain MSME Growth. MSMEs are the backbone of the Guatemalan economy, contributing to 40 percent of GDP and 77 percent of the workforce. However, access to Finance remains an important challenge, undermining the competitiveness and productivity of MSMEs. The lack of financing instruments, particularly loans, suitable for MSMEs hinder firm investment and Growth, mainly because MSME financing is perceived by financial institutions as a high risk lending activity, to a large extent due to the degree of informality and vulnerability to domestic and external shocks associated with MSMEs. The WBG seeks to catalyze productive opportunities for greater employment, through increased access to Finance for the countrys MSMEs. The expected outcome of this objective is to enhance the enabling environment and increase access to Finance, so as to expand income and employment opportunities in the long-term. 3.1 Number of microFinance and SME Finance loans provided through financial services: Baseline: 93,133 (2015) Target: 141,723 (2020)
